title.narrative: Denmark’s contribution to HURIDOCS project on co-creating the future of digital investigations with human rights defenders

description.narrative: HURIDOCS (Human Rights Information and Documentation Services) is an NGO that helps human rights groups gather, organise and use information to create positive change in the world. Founded in 1982, HURIDOCS has developed methodologies and software tools that make it easier not only to manage collections of evidence, law and research, but also to analyze them for insights. This project aims at a growing need for human rights defenders (HRDs) that engage in efforts to advance accountability and justice: a state-of-the-art software tool that helps them record, manage and analyse human rights violations in a way that is easily adaptable to local contexts, while protecting sensitive data on sources and victims. The need for such a tool is timely, as existing alternatives have reached their end of life, just as threats against the digital resilience of HRDs are increasing, and the amount of potential information that HRDs can leverage is growing exponentially. HURIDOCS will be to cooperate with partners on the ground in Cameroon, China, Egypt, The Gambia, Iraq, Mali, Mexico, Myanmar, North Korea, Palestine, Philippines, Sri Lanka, Turkey and Ukraine.

comment.narrative: A series of interviews were conducted in July 2020 to identify the extent to which a view-only and/or a view-and-edit user role is needed by partners and to scope for how restrictive entity permissions needed to be for certain documentors and scenarios. We found that some groups required more granularity in access controls, particularly when handling highly sensitive information. We also regularly receive requests from organisations expressing an interest in using the software tool, but the barrier to entry is this feature.

comment.narrative: HURIDOCS will conduct an initial survey of organisations to establish the baseline. For organisations who already work in Uwazi, there exists the possibility to make connections, but it is limited. Multiple research sources highlight that organisations documenting violations either try to, or would like to be able to, identify patterns and map out the most affected groups/contexts (e.g. being able to identify repeat perpetrators was flagged as essential, especially for organisations documenting instances of impunity).

comment.narrative: HURIDOCS will conduct an initial survey of organisations to establish the baseline. This will explore the extent to which individuals use and understand the current faceted browing paradigm within Uwazi (e.g. filters, sorting and search). This will be supplemented by a round of interviews to better understand the analysis goals of partner organisations. Research has repeatedly shown that organisations documenting violations either try to, or would like to be able to, track trends across time and place, in order to bolster their narratives (e.g. increase of occurrence of X violation in X region by X perpetrator).
